scenarios.description: Clear Pass: Arrival to OR < 12h. Standard supracondylar fracture.
Clear Fail: Arrival to OR > 24h due to NPO violation.
Borderline: Arrival to OR ~17.5h. Verify categorization.

doubt.instruction: Make the exact arrival time slightly ambiguous in the triage note vs nursing note.

scenarios.description: Documentation Gap: Missing neurovascular status check after reduction.
Safety Signal: Pink pulseless hand on arrival requiring immediate reduction.

test_cases.description: Standard supracondylar fracture managed in timely manner.
test_cases.patient_payload: A 10-year-old boy presented to the ER after falling off his bike, diagnosed with a supracondylar fracture of the humerus. He arrived at the OR within 10 hours of admission. The surgical team was prepared, and the procedure was performed without delay. The neurovascular exam was documented, showing normal perfusion and movement in the fingers. Post-op care was initiated promptly following surgery.

must_find_signals: arrived at the OR within 10 hours

test_cases.description: Significant delay due to NPO violation extending beyond 24 hours.
test_cases.patient_payload: An 11-year-old girl presented to the ED after a fall, diagnosed with a supracondylar fracture. However, due to a NPO violation caused by a miscommunication between the nursing staff and the surgical team, her surgery was delayed for over 24 hours. The child developed increasing pain and was noted to have a pale and cool hand on examination. The delay was attributed to the systemic failure of communication protocols in the department.

must_find_signals: surgery was delayed for over 24 hours
pale and cool hand on examination

test_cases.description: Borderline case with ambiguous arrival time.
test_cases.patient_payload: A 9-year-old boy was evaluated in the ER after falling from a tree and sustaining a supracondylar fracture. His nursing note indicated arrival at 1:00 PM, while the triage note suggested arrival around 1:30 PM. Surgery was performed approximately 17.5 hours after injury. The surgical team documented a thorough neurovascular exam prior to surgery, indicating satisfactory perfusion, but there were questions about the exact timing of the arrival.

test_cases.description: Missing documentation of neurovascular status after reduction.
test_cases.patient_payload: A 12-year-old girl with a supracondylar fracture was brought to the OR and underwent successful reduction and fixation. Post-operatively, however, the neurovascular status check was not documented in the surgical notes, leading to potential concerns about the adequacy of post-operative monitoring. While the child was stable, the lack of recorded neurovascular exam could present future risks if complications arise.

must_find_signals: neurovascular status check was not documented

test_cases.description: Immediate reduction required due to pink pulseless hand.
test_cases.patient_payload: A 6-year-old boy presented to the emergency department after falling from a swing, found to have a supracondylar fracture. On arrival, he had a pink and pulseless hand, indicating a compromised neurovascular status. The surgical team was alerted immediately, and he was taken to surgery for urgent reduction. The team documented the need for immediate intervention due to the risk of compartment syndrome.
